txt: I feel wary of artificial intelligence in deliberative processes.
I am a European
I am afraid of AI.
I have read the paper in full.
I often distrust the word "scale"
The dimensions of scale presented feel helpful.
I have concerns about AI facilitation.
How will we know it works - what standards, metadata, tests need to be developed to provide unbiased assurances for these scaling tools?
We need to strengthen offline democracy
Multi tasking this way is a bit difficult for me ...
Scaling deep means deliberative democracy can be normalised in the mindset of the public sphere in the same way elections already are.
LLM technology is the only way we can economically allow everyone to participate in frequent deliberative process
LLMs are less biased than humans in interpreting data at scale
Accessibility is very important to me for AI-enhanced use - we need youth voice, busy person voice, and all-language voice.
Scaling deliberation is more of a political issue rather than a technological limitation
I feel that "power" is one of the most important considerations.
We can't pay for civic AI infrastructure with any single current way of paying for tech.
If I could, I would push a button to pause AI development where it stands.
AI is better suited to the transparent filtering/clustering tool at the early stages of a deliberative process. Human always after machine.
we should only use AI for a role when we absolutely can't find a human willing/eager to perform that role
Human always before AND after machine
The word scale is often used to dilute an innovation that has proved itself but is small or expensive
The problem with democratic crisis is not technological its cultural, therefore AI is not well placed to navigate a robust societal solution
Artificialness is a dead end
We're just getting to grips with confidently using deliberative, need grounding before charging into AI or we risk losing political trust
I'm hesitatingly curious around AI supporting some of the work to make the use of deliberative processes easier and less costly to deliver
AI for scaling deliberation is diverting resources from building foundational democratic and community resilience in a time of polycrisis
AI tools offer the opportunity to create meso-level publics which can bridge the mini - maxi public gap in deliberative democratic theory
I'm concerned that we will breed out analytical, summarising, and facilitation skills in humans, already seeing this in students
Using AI to scale is not a regenerative practice and hard to justify in the context of deliberation to address the climate crisis
AI could lead to deskilling of facilitators, for example in our ability to synthesise and frame information
I am concerned that we relegating the role of "storyteller" to LLMs without thought.
AI SHOULD BE A TOOL. A HELPER, NOT MADE INTO A. NEW MASTER
Human facilitators are over praised, and while skilled facilitation is irreplaceable, AI can be a useful aid for many of us
Efficiency and cost-reduction are risky narratives in this context. Democracy is complex and costly - no shortcuts.
AI is a black box, and antithetical to transparency when used in a deciding or selecting role. (Not excluding supportive roles.)
AI has a place but should never replace human connection. Resolving the polycrisis needs more humanness, not less.
The real scaling is cognitive. The world is too complex for any one brain. We to define what it is for a community to understand something.
I trust AI in the initiation phase of deliberation, but would prefer humans to direct sensemaking.
Enhancing citizen capacity— all delib scaling should evolve in parallel with educational reform [crit. thinking/citizenship]
I greatly value the people who are demonizing AI, even if I think there are thoughtful ways to use it.
AI is the first tool we have that can also be a storyteller.
AI is better and more sustainably conceptualized as a partner more than a tool.
